comments.commentBody: The little you said means a lot. I too struggle with the idea of having a public defender as the legal counsel for someone who's financially incapable of hiring his or her own counsel.  But let's keep the debate in the right perspective, although and rightfully the article's author raised many issues. It is true however that past administration have turned blind eyes against what were Civil Rught caliber cases. Opinions are what they are: the person or persons who highlight or broadcast them. But facts will always remain facts.
Obviously, the two-tier legal system that exists in our country has escaped you.

This article raises more questions than it answers. Many of those questions get at the heart of what type nation we, as Americans, are striving to be.
For example Why is seeking competent counsel, in the event of being charged with a crime, a political issue?

I mean, the 6th and 14th amendments provide for the right to legal representation. If public defenders are overworked, and therefore unable to fulfill their duties, does that mean only the rich are entitled to their full protections afforded to them the Constitution?

If we strive to be a more just society that serves as an example to the rest of the world, everyone, regardless of class, race, or ethnicity, should be entitled to equal protections under the law.

In the field of medicine, the earlier one intervenes in a disease process, the quicker the cure, the fewer the sequelae, the lesser the pain and suffering, the shorter the recovery period, the lower the cost, and the better the overall outcome.

In law, on the other hand...

An accused's right to counsel in the criminal justice system, conditions of juvenile prisoners, and employment discrimination are hardly trivial issues comparable to a "schoolyard fight." We are a society that claims to respect civil rights. So what is the point of having a Civil Rights Division in the DOJ if it will protect the civil rights of American citizens.

The comparison to a schoolyard fight is also misleading because it suggests the fight is fair. The local governments are pulling the "why are you picking on little ole' us" routine. But let's get real. Even small municipal governments have far more power than individual citizens. Just think about the saying, "You can't fight city hall."
Congress writes laws (or they used to). The DOJ helps enforce them. Injustice that breaks the law shouldn't be  acceptable on any scale, small or large.

Why do we continue to say we are a free country with checks and balances. We are so afraid of being called names we allow this person to do as he pleases. Where are our representatives. We are going to become the country that the illegals come from just so a democrat can have a vote. Shame on every one of our representatives. Do your job.

European I know are amazed at the power of our states to thwart federal demands. For them such a concept has never existed. They went from monarchies to powerful central governments and nothing looked different to them. Berlin, Paris, London still rule as monarchs.
Even more amazing we have people in this country who think this is the way to go. Let Washington mandate all and the states just be administrators of Washington's will. What's next? Only federal elections with all others on the lower scale just be appointees?

Why continue the pretense of republican local autonomy? The Fed should just declare the fact that it is THE government of the United "States". State and local governments are mere sideshows. Similarly, new editions of the "living" Constitution should delete Article I, Section 8 about the "enumerated" powers of Congress. "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people." Congress is irrelevant given the unlimited Executive actions of the Obama administration. There is nothing that the Executive cannot do to you.

You have a problem with rectifying this wrong?:

“Criminally prosecuting those individuals for something as innocent as sleeping, when they have no safe, legal place to go, violates their constitutional rights,” Ms. Gupta said.

"Would Mr Blow care to comment on the biggest killer of black men, which is other black men?"

Well, the biggest killer of white folks is other white folks. Harping on this point perhaps gives biased individuals a sense of vindication where none exists. There is no equivalency between murder by police (who are authority figures supposed to serve and protect) and murder by a common street criminal. And, Btw, Mr. Blow did address your question in a column a few days ago. Look it up.....
Paul. ... You touch all of the salient points that needed to be said.

The whole thing felt to me like reality TV. The black activists obviously chose not to embarrass HRC by crashing her rally or disrupting an appearance, the way they did with Bernie Sanders and some of the Republicans. Coincidence? I think not.

Mrs. Clinton was the last of the major candidates to be confronted by BLM. She had many days to think about what they would say when they did confront her. Is the last major candidate by coincidence? I think not.

There were no official TV cameras there by design, but the whole thing was caught on a cell phone camera. Obviously Mrs. Clinton knew she was being filmed. So to call it a spontaneous encounter puts that word through the Looking Glass. Coincidence? I think not.

Worst of all, the story breaks on the morning of the day that her lawyer says that yes indeed, HRC's emails server was wiped. And not by a cloth, either. Coincidence? I think not.

"The activists called on Clinton to answer for her and her husband’s part in the rise of mass incarceration in this country, a phenomenon that disproportionately affects black and brown people".

That's because their criminality is disproportionate to their population in this country. Simple math Blow......
Amen!  I'm only 73, but have dedicated much of my life politically to what you say.  Let's us old geezers keep after them!
Correction:  You (Mr. Slater) don't feel you have anything to do with the problem.  In fact, you do.

OMG, she is left of center by any measure. Not liberal, not progressive, but not  "center right". If you're got concrete evidence of that in terms of policy to substantiate that, then here's your opportunity, proceed governor:

When we are demanding apologies and contrition, will it be OK to demand the same of Michelle Obama for the deportation record of Barack. I would be embarrassed for anyone who would do that. (I am a 100% supporter of President Obama and not so much of HRC.) This sort of thing is wrong headed. If you want a change then by all means, point out past mistakes and ask the candidate what they will do going forward.
Go Bernie !!

JStraight Furrow,

Please ask yourself, what sort of bent social environment gives rise to to the sad statistics you cite AND the even more sorrowful perspective you hold?

Try kicking things up a level or two in your thinking and you may come to the view that both are the chronically self-perpetuating result of a grotesquely flawed social system that is unable to correct itself.
While looking up statistics, please pay attention to the role the drug war has played in gang violence, and gun violence in general.

"The law, in its majestic equality, forbids the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets, and to steal bread."
Anatole France

Charles, it's one thing to protest excessive force by the police, but did you seriously ask why blacks are incarcerated at a higher rate than whites?

You do realize that blacks commit crimes at a higher rate than whites???

13% of the population commits over 50% of violent felonies.
The candidates on the right aren't expecting the black vote, and the black voters aren't planning to vote for them. Hence the decision to focus on the candidates who are expecting said black vote.
Let's be frank: The Republican candidates wouldn't let "those people" within 100 yards of their events. And I'm sure this is just as true for Dr. Ben Carson as it is for Scott Walker or Marco Rubio.
Pray tell, when do the BLM activists plan to confront the candidates on the right, or don't they.
They would also be  foolish to vote for Rand Paul.  Or the Koch brothers.

Re the marriage equality movement, there was also one other thing helping them: Fred Phelps and his group from Kansas showing the world the endpoint of the ugliness of homophobia. Who would want to think like them. Someone wants to commit to their loved one? For the sake of honoring each other? Let's celebrate!

Do you remember Ralph Nader's little holier than thou kick?  How did that work out?  Hilary is a long way from perfect, but she at least sort of cares that poor children grow up fed, educated, and vaccinated well enough to have a chance in life.  That is utterly untrue of any conceivable Republican nominee.  You are letting this enemy of the merely good get thing get seriously out of hand.
When the federal mandatory sentencing guidelines were passed in the 1980s, several federal judges resigned in protest.  They foresaw what was coming.

Wow, Mr. Blow seems unable to respond to the questions this exchange posses.  He focuses on blame and accountability without offering any constructive dialogue.  We can't change the past, we can never make up for the country's sins.  I agree with Hillary, the change begins with policy, changing laws, constructive action that makes a difference in the lives of all black people.  Hillary may have been a part of an ill conceived policy, but it seems as though she has learned something from it. I don't here her making excuses, I see an honest and respectful dialogue happening in the video.  It is her job to make policy if elected, but she seems to understand that this policy making shouldn't occur in a vacuum.   We need the activist to work towards  having a voice in policy, we need them to demand change, we need them to offer solutions.  They have done an excellent job of giving a voice to the victims of racist hatred, both institutional and personal.  Now we need them to become a part of the process, to get involve in proposing solutions.  If I had any doubts about Hillary, many of them have been laid to rest after viewing this meaningful exchange.

This is a magazine where in excess of 75% of the content can be ads. Hundreds of pages of ads. It seems appropriate to treat it like a magazine that people read "for the pictures."

It's interesting that Beyoncé is practicing tactical silence and that it appears to be working, or at least not diminishing her stardom in any way. But I think most celebrities at her stratosphere can be similar in temperament, including engaging in branding strategies that don't involve social media, which is not necessary to their continued success.

If you make a quick study of celebrities who aren't active on social media, you will also find that many of them are married couples or long established, like Beyoncé.

At a certain point you need to ask what these "interviews" are. If I go looking for an interview from a celebrity, I try to look for something along the quality of an Inside the Actors Studio event. Substantive interviews like this are rare.

One reason this epidemic of brutality has prospered has been the lack of protest from the "good guys".
If Hillary and Bernie want the support of the black community it seems reasonable to expect them to earn it.

tommydew - The answer is that no one from BLM can get anywhere near a GOP candidate. All their interactions with the public are screened and scripted. The only person who can get to them is Trump - if you consider his remarks helpful.

"Why are the BLM activists only confronting Bernie and Hillary, the only two presidential candidates that might actually want to help with our racism problem?" Probably for the same reasons that anti-war activists during the Vietnam Era protested Lyndon Johnson, or maybe for the same reasons that anti-war voters gave Clinton such a tough time during the 2008 elections. If you actually look closely at her and the Clinton Administration's record on policing and criminal justice, black people have a fair amount to be displeased about. We should really look beyond the surface level examination where "Hillary Clinton = Democrat = great on race". A more careful reading, as noted in the column, suggests her record (and many Dems during the 80s and 90s) leaves a lot to be desired. Somehow we can appreciate nuance in evaluating left-of-center candidates' positions on foreign policy and economics (i.e. Hillary Clinton does not = Bernie Sanders does not = Chuck Schumer), but incapable of that in evaluating them on criminal justice or race. There are no camps in discussion of race... Dems are good, Republicans are bad. Actual voting records and documented policy positions don't matter.

Why are the BLM activists only confronting Bernie and Hillary, the only two presidential candidates that might actually want to help with our racism problem? Why aren't they confronting the GOP candidates who have no interest in solving these problems? I want to see how Scott Walker and Jeb Bush and Marco Rubio react. I want to see them squirm when confronted by genuinely angry, concerned citizens. Let's hear their answers to our racial problem. Bashing Hillary has become so easy and tiresome. Start going after the truely bad guys that want to be president.

And it can become something bigger: now, talk about her silence makes it even more powerful. She has gone through a kind of breakthrough about different things before the release of her "4" album. It reflected on her music but also on her public persona; it's clear to see that notions of stardom, such an important part of her early solo career, were all redefined. Personally, I see it as something really refreshing. And it seems to be working very well for her too.

Maybe Beyonce feels she is a just an entertainer and prefers to communicate primarily through her music.  It is career suicide to avoid social media entirely so she does it her way through posting photographs to Instagram and making what appears to be motivational tweets.  I am tired of celebrities going on and on about their political views, medical "advice," and TMI about their personal and intimate lives.  Good for Beyonce for maintaining some degree of privacy.

Wow! What an absolute hodge-podge of a piece Blow has penned today! To paraphrase Blow’s first paragraph, I found myself caught between laughing out loud in derision and shaking my head in disgust.

Expecting Hillary to admit that she was wrong about any of her own or Bill’s past misdeeds? Give me a break. To do so would be an act of political suicide.

Then, what is with the tone of Blow’s writing these days? It swings from the rational to attempts at thundering righteous moral indignation. All things considered, the injustices suffered by the poor in America these days, and mostly those who are people of color, needs to be fixed. But, it does not rise to the level of the civil rights fight of the 1960’s. Blow’s tone of near hysteria on racial matters is detracting from the need for targeted reforms.

The just changes Blow and others should be focusing on are:
• De-criminalization of petty offenses,
• Bail reform,
• Assistance instead of incarceration for low level offenses, and
• The de-militarization of our local police forces.

These changes would probably reduce one-third to one-half of the human resources and expenditures we are needlessly throwing away on law enforcement, courts and maintaining the largest penal infrastructure in the free world. Those are resources that could be better channeled towards educating our children and making our communities better places.

All lives matter.
